It's worth knowing HOW Hemingway broke with Gloria, the trans daughter: She was arrested for going to a movie "in female clothing." Hemingway called Gloria's mother, who had a stress-based medical condition, to scream at her. The mother died and Hemingway told Gloria she'd killed her by being trans.

I don't necessarily mind it as a historical exercise. But I feel the same way about a trans read of Hemingway as I would about a potential trans read of Elon Musk: Sure, maybe Hemingway repressed some gender feelings, maybe that explains why Hemingway was so shitty to women, but that's no excuse.

Forgive the Substacksubtweeting, but building "platforms" has to come after answering the questions: Why do you, specifically, need the platform? Who are you going to help with your platform, and how? If those people need to sacrifice to build your platform, what will you give them in return?

I think if you approach being a journalist or political writer, especially for marginalized perspectives, as a matter of building a "brand" or getting your name out there, you will burn out very fast. Every internet platform has a Nazi problem (and a CSAM problem, and a harassment problem, and and and): it's inherent to the concept of letting anyone use your platform. Most platforms are significantly better at handling it than Substack, and it's hard to get worse.

Ideally, you are a public servant in this job. You name names. You take off masks. You tell the truth. I think the constant reality-show drama of Twitter, who's friends with who, who's cool, who's not, led journalists to think WE were the point, and we never have been.

You do not know my Mom's name. She hasn't worked as a journalist since 1985. To the extent her life changed, it was just that she got a bunch of death threats. But she made the lives of Black people in that town measurably safer, through telling the truth. That's the job, not building a Brand(TM).

At the time, a lot of the Klan's mystique, and a lot of their terror, came from the idea that they could be anyone -- that all the most powerful people in society were Klan members, that you were never safe. She let people know that they were just a handful of guys who worked in a specific factory.

Like: Here is a story I think about often. My mom doxed a bunch of Klan members in the early '80s. She told them she wasn't allowed to interview them under conditions of anonymity. They had to give the interview with the hoods off. Then she found their names and where they worked and published it.

I benefited from the blog era as much as anyone, more than most people, but I think that the whole social media gestalt where journalism comes down to acquiring Fans and building a Personal Brand has been overall bad for the world and we all know it

Yeah, but even as she says it, she's talking about writing a domestic violence narrative -- which does not take a pro-domestic-violence stance -- and she's saying things like "we live in a sexist, racist, white supremacist bullshit society." Morality and politics are both clearly a part of her work.

People who are most passionately for "transgression" or against "morality" in art are almost always very strict moralists themselves -- their work is often didactic and they take their own moral code quite seriously. Which is fine! But just say that instead of claiming to go Beyond Good And Evil!

I mean, conceivably a completely abstract narrative -- like a filmed Rothko canvas or pure glossolalia -- could exist, and could be both amoral and apolitical. But even something like "Un Chien Andalou" had a politics and a morality in that it exposed the absurdity & violence of the modern world.

And if you want to talk about evil billionaires using feminism or art to launder their reputations, yeah, that’s worth talking about. But it’s an ongoing situation that affects a lot of people you like, not a uniquely terrible thing done only once by that annoying Hannah Gadsby.

So it’s not that “Hannah Gadsby took Sackler money.” It’s that, for a long-ass time, one of the only major backers of feminist art in the United States has been Sackler money. It’s a shitty, terrible situation that implicates basically every major feminist artist.

The Sackler Center for Feminist Art has been part of the Brooklyn Museum for as long as I can remember. It’s why Judy Chicago’s “The Dinner Party” is on permanent exhibit there. They’ve done shows on Kathe Kollwitz, Georgia O’Keefe, & stuff like this:

People (including myself) became absurdly defensive and fragile because to admit fault was the same as admitting you were worthless and evil and shouldn’t be posting. We all learned to read each other in the worst possible faith & to construct plausible paranoid readings of every statement.

A lot of good-faith dialogue got warped by Tumblr’s gamification model, whereby you “won” if you could find a way to read someone’s statement as problematic and call them out, and to call someone “privileged” or “problematic” was the same as calling them evil or knocking them out of the game.

You hear this a lot about masculinity — that it’s never a given, always in the process of being proved. Wondering if you’re a real man, needing to prove you’re a real man, is what being a man feels like. But femininity is always being proved & performed too. There’s always danger of doing it wrong.

One thing I’ve been thinking about is that, within the gender binary, “man” and “woman” are stereotypes so narrow that basically no one fits them. Trans people make cis people uncomfortable, not because our un-fitting is obvious, but because it makes them realize all the ways they don’t fit either.

This, from Alan Watts in the 1960s, reads like somebody complaining about TikTok

We’ve built an engine that makes it possible for masses of people to follow you wherever you go and scream threats and abuse at you. The human brain was not designed to cope with having millions of invisible enemies surrounding you every second. It’s a pain box. I don’t want to build another one.

Probably 98% of the people who put me in trauma treatment would not have done what they did, if they were able to grasp that they were torturing another human being. They just didn’t see that. They were participating in normal behavior encouraged by the site’s structure and posting culture.

Anyway: As someone who now has to limit his hours on social media because the sight of a feed is a trauma trigger, we have to be careful about how we design these machines and the culture we build with them. The human nervous system can’t tolerate some of the shit we do here.

And, again: They weren’t bad people. They aren’t. It was frustrating, because as the trauma got deeper, I got more volatile, I got teary, I got jumpy, I had rage, I had a hard time advocating for myself because words wouldn’t come. I looked crazier as I got more hurt, I wasn’t my best me either.

Some of those people were even IRL friends, which is probably where the clinically significant trauma came from — I had felt safe around them, I trusted them, and I was learning that I had been unsafe the entire time and hadn’t seen it, so there was nowhere to run. No way to feel safe, ever.

It’s emotionally difficult, because I am confident that a ton of the people who did this were not bad people. They were on the left, we shared certain values, and they saw themselves just adding one small piece to the pile. They couldn’t know the weight of that pile to someone who was underneath it.

Again: I don’t think Twitter harassment “gave” me PTSD so much as it retraumatized me and caused a big flare-up in the symptoms that were already there. And in a weird way, that crisis forced me to get the help I needed. So I am at peace with it having happened, to the extent I can be.

This is a weird bit of earnestposting, but, after a rough few election cycles where I got a lot of harassment on Twitter, I wound up in treatment for C-PTSD. I almost certainly had PTSD before 2016, but by late 2019 it was physically unbearable. It was much worse. I’m still coming back from that.
